thread.title: Leicester property investment firm Custodian Reit sees portfolio value jump £73m to £547m in a year - Leicestershire Live

author: Tom Pegden
title: Leicester property investment firm Custodian Reit sees portfolio value jump £73m to £547m in a year - Leicestershire Live
text:
News Leicester property investment firm Custodian Reit sees portfolio value jump £73m to £547m in a year But business warns “conundrum of a ‘soft Brexit’ or a ‘no deal Brexit’" is increasingly occupying investors’ thoughts Share The Custodian Reit offices in New Walk Leicester Get Business
Leicester property investment business Custodian Reit has seen the value of its portfolio rise substantially in the last year from £474 million to £547 million.
Pre-tax profits were up 26 per cent to £16.6 million at the city centre business on the back of a “cautious” approach to buying high quality regional property while disposing of weaker retail sites.
The New Walk business invested £27.7 million during the year in seven acquisitions, one development and one refurbishment, and made a profit of £4.3 million on the sale of three properties for a total of £15.4 million.
While business was good for the company - launched as a spin-off to wealth management and pensions firm Mattioli Woods - interim results for the year to September 30 warned that the “conundrum of a ‘soft Brexit’ or a ‘ no deal Brexit ’ appears increasingly to be occupying investors’ thoughts”.
David Hunter, chairman of Custodian REIT, said: “I am pleased to report another successful period of positive shareholder returns and cautious investment in a market where value can still be found with a disciplined approach to deployment. Read More Mattioli Woods “well placed” for growth despite market caution and Brexit uncertainty
“The board and investment manager are closely monitoring the potential impact of evolving trends in the UK retail industry and ‘Brexit’ on commercial property markets.
“Our role is to look beyond the media coverage to weigh up dispassionately the associated risks, which often create opportunity, and we expect proactive asset management will continue to drive performance in the portfolio, as rental growth at lease renewal or rent review remains robust.
“We also expect occupational demand, combined with a limited supply of new development, to maintain low vacancy rates across our regional portfolio.” Like us on Facebook
